author: SamHarrisOrg

text: We pull ourselves up by our bootstraps everywhere in science and philosophy. We don't justify the claim that events have causes, or that some memories are veridical, or that 2 + 9 = 11, and we need not justify the claim that pointless misery is bad and worth avoiding.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text:
IS/OUGHT
Certain states of pointless misery are possible—i.e. extreme suffering from which no good ever comes—how can we avoid these experiences? Saying we “ought” to avoid them adds nothing to the import of the phrase “pointless misery.”
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: Who said anything about "physical"? Even if gratitude is made of ectoplasm, my argument would be unchanged.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: No. It was a reference to my argument (in previous tweets).
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: You need more time with your stove. Forget about "ought": The difference between excruciating and pointless misery and sublime happiness remains. See what you do when given a choice between (and call that imperative you feel whatever you want).
author: SamHarrisOrg

text:
You can't coherently assert the existence of any "is" without invoking an "ought." (e.g., Self contradiction *ought* to be avoided.) 
You are making demands on moral philosophy that we don't make on physics.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: Yes, when your actions can affect no one else, we don't talk about "morality" or "ethics"—but terms like "value" and "well-being" still apply. You could think of having a moral/ethical connection to your future self, however.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: Tell that to your stove.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: Look at it from the other side: Try to get to an "is" without obeying a few "oughts" (logical coherence, respect for evidence, etc.) This IS/OUGHT divide is a fiction.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: Either you don't understand "fewer" or "suck." Or you're not making a serious attempt to think this through.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: Another way to come at it. See our podcasts together... https://twitter.com/JaxonDechanel/status/951307563437625344 …
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: Point out the flaws in it.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: *Actual* experiences are sufficient for my argument. (And I might well be an actualist.) Whatever happens next, there is a vast difference between the best and worst outcomes. We can't help but try to navigate between them.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: This is what I mean when I talk about morality as a "navigation problem."
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: 8/ So what is morality? What *ought* sentient beings like ourselves do? Understand how the world works (facts), so that we can avoid what sucks (values).
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: 7/ We can also be selfish and shortsighted. Many solutions to our problems are zero-sum (my gain will be your loss). But *better* solutions aren’t. (By what measure of “better”? Fewer things suck.)
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: 6/ Of course, we can be confused or mistaken about experience. Something can suck for a while, only to reveal new experiences which don’t suck at all. On these occasions we say, “At first that sucked, but it was worth it!”
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: 5/ If we *should* to do anything in this life, we should avoid what really and truly sucks. (If you consider this question-begging, consult your stove, as above.)
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: 4/ Conscious minds are natural phenomena. Consequently, if we were to learn everything there is to know about physics, chemistry, biology, psychology, economics, etc., we would know everything there is to know about making our corner of the universe suck less.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: 3/ Unfortunately, many experiences suck. And they don’t just suck as a matter of cultural convention or personal bias—they really and truly suck. (If you doubt this, place your hand on a hot stove and report back.)
author: SamHarrisOrg

text: 2/ Among the myriad things that exist are conscious minds, susceptible to a vast range of actual (and possible) experiences.
author: SamHarrisOrg

text:
Getting from “Is” to “Ought” 

1/ Let’s assume that there are no ought’s or should’s in this universe. There is only what *is*—the totality of actual (and possible) facts.
